comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: Such an abomination has replaced that time board, the pot plants and moulded chairs are classics aren't they?

comment.author: 28304000@N00
comment._content: By the time this photo was taken the departures board had already outlived it's usefulness and lacked the flexibility required by the timetable as testified by the numerous supplementary metal signs that had to be used. This was mainly due to the decrease in long distance country trains and the vast increase in shorter distance commuter intercity trains.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/albert3801] From memory on the Southern Highlands line the only thing that changed was the clock at the top, the destinations remained unchanged. Might have been different on other lines I suppose.
In any case it was a lovely bit of old world. I'm glad they preserved in in the Powerhouse Museum.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/albert3801] Those metal signs on the floor look like someone isn't coping very well as you say.

comment.author: 28304000@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] What used to happen is that columns for country and less frequent trains would be "borrowed" for thenumerous  North, West and Illawarra Interurbans. Because the columns didn't have the correct destinations on the flip over slats, the supplementary metal signs were hung up on those less frequently used columns.

comment.author: 72229207@N00
comment._content: There are a lot of places to sit on the concourse in 1981! Yes the potplants and moulded chairs give it a 1970s sitting-room kind of aesthetic.
